001package io.github.ai4ci.flow.mechanics;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004
005import io.github.ai4ci.abm.ImmutableOutbreakHistory;
006import io.github.ai4ci.abm.ImmutableOutbreakState;
007import io.github.ai4ci.abm.ImmutablePersonHistory;
008import io.github.ai4ci.abm.ImmutablePersonState;
009import io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState;
010import io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonState;
011import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
012
013/**
014 * This abstraction lets us have policy and behaviour models sharing the same
015 * state model framework, so outbreak and person updates can follow the same
016 * pattern. This is the super-type for {@link State.PolicyState} and
017 * {@link State.BehaviourState}.
018 *
019 * <br>
020 * <br>
021 * Each state machine state has 2 methods in it that alter the behaviour of the
022 * outbreak or agent. firstly the
023 * {@link #updateHistory(Object, Object, StateMachineContext, Sampler)} method
024 * which is run at the end of each day and allows the population of data points
025 * that are specific to {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonHistory} or
026 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakHistory}. Usually this means
027 *
028 * @param <BUILDER> builder of either outbreak state (policy) or person state
029 *                  (behaviour).
030 * @param <HISTORY> builder of either outbreak history (policy) or person
031 *                  history (behaviour).
032 * @param <STATE>   the current state of the entity (e.g. OutbreakState (policy)
033 *                  or behaviour state)
034 * @param <X>       the super-type of allowable state models.
035 */
036public interface State<BUILDER, HISTORY, STATE, X extends State<BUILDER, HISTORY, STATE, X>>
037                extends Serializable {
038
039        /**
040         * Marks a state model as being a component of a behaviour relevant to people
041         * within the simulation
042         */
043        interface BehaviourState extends
044                        State<ImmutablePersonState.Builder, ImmutablePersonHistory.Builder, PersonState, BehaviourState> {
045                @Override
046                public default String name() {
047                        return "Behaviour";
048                }
049        }
050
051        /**
052         * Marks a state model state as being a component of a policy for managing to
053         * the outbreak simulation as a whole
054         */
055        interface PolicyState extends
056                        State<ImmutableOutbreakState.Builder, ImmutableOutbreakHistory.Builder, OutbreakState, PolicyState> {
057                @Override
058                public default String name() {
059                        return "Policy";
060                }
061        }
062
063        /**
064         * The states in the state model are all enum fields. This provides a hook
065         * back into the definition so we can tell if it is a policy or behaviour
066         * model state. This is largely used for displaying the name of the policy or
067         * behaviour model from the individual state it is in.
068         *
069         * @return the class of the Enum of this policy or behaviour state.
070         */
071        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
072        default Class<State<BUILDER, HISTORY, STATE, X>> getEnumClass() {
073                return (Class<State<BUILDER, HISTORY, STATE, X>>) ((Enum<?>) this)
074                                .getDeclaringClass();
075        }
076
077        /**
078         * The name of the state, which is the enum name prefixed by the enum class
079         * name. This is used for display purposes, and to make it clear which model
080         * a state belongs to when looking at the state of an individual person or
081         * the outbreak.
082         *
083         * @return the name of the state, which is the enum name prefixed by the enum
084         *         class name.
085         */
086        default String getName() {
087                return this.getEnumClass().getSimpleName() + "." + this.name();
088        }
089
090        /**
091         * The name of the model that this state belongs to, which is the enum class
092         * name. This is used for display purposes, and to make it clear which model
093         * a state belongs to when looking at the state of an individual person or
094         * the outbreak.
095         *
096         * @return the name of the model that this state belongs to, which is the
097         *         enum class name.
098         */
099        String name();
100
101        /**
102         * This is the hook for changing the behaviour in the model in terms of
103         * mobility, compliance etc in person/behavioural models, or changing system
104         * wide properties in outbreak/policy models. These changes can be thought of
105         * as happening at the start of a day in relation to the information
106         * available from the day before. Because of this limitation it is difficult
107         * for the model to react to things that happen on the same day. To some
108         * extent reflex testing is possible as the result of a test can be known
109         * instantly.
110         *
111         * <br>
112         * <br>
113         * This method both decides what the future behaviour or policy will be based
114         * on the current state, but can also change the future state by calling the
115         * builder parameter's methods. This is the main place in which future state
116         * is affected by behaviour, and a lot of the effects are implemented as
117         * static methods in {@link StateUtils}.
118         *
119         * <br>
120         * <br>
121         * The implementation of the nextState method in policy models can influence
122         * both the next state of the Outbreak (via the builder) but also can
123         * influence the next state of people within the outbreak indirectly by
124         * iterating through the agents and calling
125         * {@link StateUtils#branchPeopleTo(io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakState, io.github.ai4ci.abm.mechanics.StateMachine.BehaviourState)}
126         * which will force an immediate change in the individuals persons behaviour
127         * model state, {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Person#getStateMachine()} on each
128         * of them.
129         *
130         * <br>
131         * <br>
132         * Other changes are possible by interacting with
133         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.Person#getNextState()} (the next person state
134         * builder, which will be populated by the time this method is called).
135         * Changes made in this way by a policy model could be changed back if
136         * dictated by the person's behaviour model so this is less reliable than
137         * authoring a behaviour that specifically updates the persons state in
138         * response to a policy state change.
139         *
140         * @param builder the builder for the future state of the agent or outbreak.
141         * @param current the current state of the agent or outbreak.
142         * @param context the previous states and other context for the state model
143         * @param rng     a random number generator
144         * @return The behaviour or policy state for the next time step, but side
145         *         effects on the state of the builder are expected.
146         */
147        X nextState(
148                        BUILDER builder, STATE current, StateMachineContext context,
149                        Sampler rng
150        );
151
152        /**
153         * Depending on the type this updated the outbreak or person history, and
154         * this is the hook for changing the testing, or adding in contacts /
155         * exposures if we are looking at people. Use case is less clear for
156         * outbreak/policy, as there is less stored here. The implementation for
157         * outbreak (PolicyModel) makes this a no-op. This is called during the
158         * history stage of the update cycle, and effectively performs actions that
159         * are done at the end of the day.
160         *
161         * @param builder the next PersonHistory builder (usually)
162         * @param current the current PersonHistory
163         * @param context the previous states and other context for the state model
164         * @param rng     the sampler
165         */
166        void updateHistory(
167                        HISTORY builder, STATE current, StateMachineContext context,
168                        Sampler rng
169        );
170}
